last_post.content:
In a big chunk of the call, we discuss why a full-fledged OSS app like @elk is beneficial to the @vite, @nuxt, and Vue ecosystems.

Improvements to Vite plugins, Vue libs, and Nuxt modules (even new ones created from the App needs). And huge amount of DX and UX data to further enhance them and test new ideas in the future.

Some of the most active maintainers of plugins and modules have integrated their libs themselves into the project. Diving into the code base of Elk could help you learn more about these tools and how they play together.

The developer in me sees the benefit, but the carefree hacker in me just shrugs.

Aristotle claimed that identical regular tetrahedra could be packed in a way that fills space. It seems unlikely if you actually try it - but only in 1925 was it proved impossible. And only in 2010 did people prove a nontrivial upper bound on the density of the packing you can achieve, namely

0.9999999999999999999999974

On the other hand, the densest known packing has density about .8563 - there's a discussion and picture on Wolfram's website:

last_post.content:
Surprisingly not a still from a sci-fi movie, this new #JWST image shows us the central portion of the star-forming Chamaeleon I molecular cloud.

The cold, wispy cloud material (blue, center) is illuminated in the infrared by the glow of the young, outflowing protostar Ced 110 IRS 4 (orange, upper left). The ices in the cloud absorb some of the light of background stars (orange dots), allowing us to detect them.

Remarkable new intracortical speech prosthesis BCI from Francis Willett, Erin Kunz, and colleages at Stanford. https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.01.21.524489v1

They achieved 23.8% word error rate on a 125k word vocabulary. Not only a huge step over previous systems, but that WER approaches Android's built-in speech recognition!

Also, successful decoding at 62 WPM (3.4x previous SotA). Really remarkable. And, at least at a high level, the ML architecture is surprisingly simple!

-Obey the Mastodon Covenant (but doesn't have to be running Mastodon)

-Be open for public registration, either directly or through requests

Unlike https://instances.social etc this site is curated.

(1/2)

🎩 to @annaleen for this bonkers #dataviz from Quartz, showing how BAS's "doomsday clock" has moved back and forth since Martyl Langsdorf’s design was unveiled in 1947.

BAS’s decision in 2007 to factor climate disruption into the mix makes perfect sense for obvious big-picture reasons, but less obvious is the ‘inflationary’ effect that decision had on perceived risk. From the day before the decision to the day after, the only thing that changed was how BAS ‘measured’ the threat of annihilation. But, in effect, every estimate prior to 2007 became incommensurate — and, weirdly, everything before 2007 ended up looking like the good old days.

It’s worth noting BAS made that change on the eve of the 2008 financial meltdown, when the scale of losses and bailouts mounted by orders of magnitude that would have seemed beyond comprehension just weeks or even days before. And just as the doomsday clock retroactively recasts the entire Cold War as good times, 2008 made the numbers associated with earlier financial spasms seem measly in comparison (the 1984 Chrysler bailout, for example: $1.5B).

Weirdly enough, WiReD has maintained a lively critical analysis of BAS’s clock for years now, including what for me is the central issue. The closer the clock is moved to midnight, the more likely it is to fuel fatalism rather than activism. Maybe we need a metaclock to measure the BAS clock's accuracy? If so, i hope this unreadable helter-skelter diagram ain’t it.

A Google search for WiReD's stories 2007–today, with the obligatory out-of-scope nonsense Google helpfully adds so they can make more money: https://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=%22doomsday%20clock%22%20site%3Awired.com#ip=1
